<b:section-contents id='sidebar-right-1'>
  <b:widget id='HTML2' locked='false' title='About Misty' type='HTML'>
    <b:widget-settings>
      <b:widget-setting name='content'><!-- Headshot -->
<div class="headshot"></div>

<div class="review-wrapper">
    <div class="review yelp">
      <a href="http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-misty-soldwisch-home-selling-team-indianola">
        <i class="vm  icon-yelp"></i>
         </a>
        </div>
      <div class="review zillow">
      <a href="http://www.zillow.com/profile/Misty-SOLDwisch-Team/">
         <i class="vm icon-zillow"></i>
      </a>
     </div>
    <div class="review trulia">
      <a href="http://www.trulia.com/profile/the-misty-soldwisch-team-broker-indianola-ia-236926/overview">
        <i class="vm icon-trulia">
      </i></a>
    </div>
<div class="review itunes">
       <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/central-iowa-real-estate-podcast/id941324237?mt=2">
          <i class="vm icon-podcast"></i><span>Subscribe to our Podcast</span>
       </a>
    </div> 
</div>



<p>My goal in life, both professionally and personally, is to treat people well.</p>

<p>I grew up in Indianola and after leaving for a few years to live in Colorado, I returned to Iowa to start a family. My husband Keith and 4 amazing children Sebastian (18), Nathaniel (16), Mirabelle (10), Ethan (9) are so supportive and inspiring!</p>

<p>I have been in the real estate business for since 2000 and in 2007 I became Broker/Owner of RE/MAX Innovations--an opportunity to combine the best of having a small-town business with a big-time network. In 2012 I opened a second location in West Des Moines with my husband, Keith, serving as the managing broker.  In 2014, I was honored to be named #1 Team Leader in the Iowa/Nebraska region for RE/MAX, for both gross sales and number of transactions. With RE/MAX Innovations, I have the ability to custom-tailor marketing strategies and provide the very best service to my clients.  We truly have the BEST, most innovative real estate talent in Central Iowa!​</p>

<p>Professional service with an emphasis on guidance, planning, and dedication to my clients' needs are my top priority. My greatest strength as a realtor is my ability to think outside the box--whether it is developing a unique marketing strategy or highlighting the potential in a property with my decorating and staging skills. I am a proactive, hands-on agent that is willing to do what it takes to meet your real estate needs.</p>

<p>In addition, offering a unique TEAM approach – where we have specialized roles in each step of the process —ensures an unparalleled expertise and customer service experience.  We know that real estate transactions can be stressful and of great financial value to our clients—it is important to work with full time professionals with your best interest at heart!</p>

entry.title: Get the Home You Want Through a Backup Offer
entry.content:
Frustrated homebuyers in the Central Iowa market may be able to use the backup offer strategy to their advantage.
Want to sell your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report
Want to buy a Central Iowa home? Search all the homes on the MLS
A lot of Central Iowa homebuyers are frustrated right now. Certain segments of the market are on fire, and they arenâ€™t able to get into homes fast enough. As a result, they feel they donâ€™t have very many homes to choose from. There may still be hope if you use the backup offer strategy. In the past, once a home went under contract, thereâ€™s very little chance for a competing buyer to get their foot in the door. Once the seller had chosen another buyerâ€™s offer, typically they made it to the closing table with no problems. However, in those super hot segments of the market, we are seeing a higher fallout rate. Why is that? First of all, many buyers feel like they need to make a quick decision in those market segments or they will lose the home. As a result, itâ€™s very common for people to make offers on a home without fully vetting the property to make sure itâ€™s the right home for them.
If the first deal falls apart, the seller has your offer to fall back on.
Secondly, multiple offer situations really drive up the price of a home. Buyers then have very high expectations of how that home will perform during the inspection. Buyers and sellers have a hard time agreeing what condition the property should be in, which has led to a number of deals falling apart after the home inspection. Having a backup offer in place puts pressure on that first offer. If for any reason that deal falls apart, the seller would much rather go to your offer than go through the hassle of putting the home on the market again. Plus, since you have a backup offer in place, the seller may be more willing to let the first deal fall apart. Not all agents can navigate the ins and outs of the backup offer, but we work hard at honing our skills in order to give our buyers the edge in this competitive market. If you have any questions about this strategy or anything else, just give us a call or send us an email. Remember, if we choose your question for one of our upcoming videos, youâ€™ll get a free subscription to Better Homes and Gardens magazine. We look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: Get the Home You Want Through a Backup Offer

entry.title: 3 Easy and Helpful Moving Hacks
entry.content:
As a home seller, how do you know which offer to pick in a multiple offer situation? 

Want to sell your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report
Want to buy a Central Iowa home? Search all the homes on the MLS
If you're moving, these three tips should help you out quite a bit:

1. Don't pick a peak day to move: In the central Iowa market, Fridays and Saturdays are the peak days, as well as the 1st, 30th, and 31st of each month. 2. Pack smart: You can read about some great moving hacks here. They'll help you plan, organize, and execute the process of getting all your belongings together efficiently. On top of these hacks, you should try to take the emotion out of packing. It's hard to avoid taking a trip down memory lane when you pack your stuff, but try to save it for when you're in your new place.
Avoid moving on peak days if at all possible.
3. Use our moving truck: This is a big advantage to working with us. We'll even give you the manpower to help you move things. Our truck isn't some rickety old truck either; it's shiny and new!

If you're thinking about making a move and need to buy and or sell a home, give us a call or send us an email. We'd love to help!

entry.title: What Should You Do When There Are Multiple Offers on Your Home?
entry.content:
As a home seller, how do you know which offer to pick in a multiple offer situation? 

Want to sell your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report
Want to buy a Central Iowa home? Search all the homes on the MLS

The central Iowa real estate market is pretty hot right now, which creates unique challenges for buyers and sellers. For sellers, itâ€™s incredibly important that you choose an agent who has experience with multiple offer situations, as they are common in our market.

When you receive multiple offers on your home, how do you know which is the best one? There are a few things you should consider:

1. Price. Obviously, we want to maximize your equity and get you the best price available for your home. Our expertise really comes in handy when it comes to looking at the full terms of the offer, because the offer with the highest price is not necessarily the best one for your interests.

2. What kind of time frame are they looking for? How flexible will the buyer be on possession? As a seller, that can make or break your ability to get into your next property, so itâ€™s important to know that up front.
The offer with the highest price is not always the best one for you.
3. What kind of contingencies does this buyer have that might cause stumbling blocks in the process? Inspections, HOA documents, or having a survey completed are just a few examples of little things that might seem irrelevant, especially if the buyer is offering a high price. However, each of those contingencies gives the buyer a chance to renegotiate after theyâ€™ve won the deal, which could make the transaction unpleasant for you.

4. What are the financing terms? We love cash offers, but cash isnâ€™t always better than financing. Someone who has a loan commitment is just as important as someone who has cash. The fortunate thing about working with an experienced agent is we know what to expect from different lenders. We know if a buyer is working with a reputable lender or a lender that weâ€™ve had issues with in the past.

Ultimately, we will sit down, look at all your different options, and work together to make sure that your needs are being met and that you choose the best offer possible.

If you have any other questions about selling your home in our current market, just give us a call. We would be happy to help you!

link.title: What Should You Do When There Are Multiple Offers on Your Home?

entry.title: When Is the Right Time to Downsize?
entry.content:
Before you decide to downsize from your current home, ask yourself these three questions. 

Want to sell your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report
Want to buy a Central Iowa home? Search all the homes on the MLS
One question we are asked on a pretty regular basis by clients is, â€œHow do I know when the right time to downsize is?â€ There are some very important questions you need to ask yourself in order to determine this.

1. Can you really live with less space? A lot of empty nesters realize that they donâ€™t need as much space or as many rooms but when it comes down to it, a lot of them arenâ€™t ready to give things up to fit in a smaller space. If youâ€™re not ready to give up some of the luxuries of having a large home, downsizing doesnâ€™t make sense right now.
Can you really live with less space?
2. Are you ready for a truly lower-maintenance lifestyle? Going from a large home to a condo or townhome leaves you with less yard work, less maintenance, and less square footage to take care of. If that sounds like an exciting change in your life, itâ€™s something for you to consider.
3. What kind of equity position do you have on your home? If you are in a great market, the timing might be perfect for you to maximize the equity you will pull out of the home. It might be time for you to talk to us if that is the case.
If you have any questions for us or are looking to buy or sell in Des Moines, give us a call or send us an email. We look forward to hearing from you.

link.title: When Is the Right Time to Downsize?

entry.title: How Do Home Warranties Benefit Both Buyers and Sellers?
entry.content:
Why do we recommend that every home buyer or seller gets a home warranty? Here are the benefits that warranties provide. 

Want to sell your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report
Want to buy a Central Iowa home? Search all the homes on the MLS

Whether you are a home buyer or a seller, one thing that we always think is a good idea to include in your real estate transaction is a home warranty. What is a home warranty? Itâ€™s an agreement with a warranty provider to cover the mechanical systems and moving parts of your home for a period of time. Warranties usually last up to one year after the closing. How do home warranties benefit buyers? The biggest benefit is that it significantly reduces the potential for large, out-of-pocket expenses after the home purchase. When we consider everything that is included in the homeâ€”appliances, the HVAC, electrical systems, and plumbing to name a fewâ€”the peace of mind that comes from knowing that a provider will cover any issues is critically important.  
Warranties usually last up to one year after the closing.
How does a home warranty work? Whenever you experience an issue during that warranty coverage period, youâ€™ll contact the warranty provider rather than your local plumber or handyman. They will connect you with one of their preferred providers and come out to look at the home. There will be a service charge up front, which you will know when you have the warranty coverage in place. They will then repair the item, and if theyâ€™re not able to do so, then they will replace it for you.
How does a home warranty benefit sellers? Most warranty providers provide free listing coverage during the time that your home is on the market. It is also a wonderful way to eliminate your liability after the closing in the event that anything goes wrong for that buyer. Our personal warranty provider is HWA Warranty. They have an awesome platinum warranty that covers the home for 13 months, rather than the 12 months covered by most providers. We have had a lot of success with it and think that it is well worth the cost to provide our buyers with peace of mind after they have purchased their largest investment. If you have any other questions about how a home warranty can benefit you or anything else related to real estate in Central Iowa, feel free to give me a call or send me an email. Iâ€™d be happy to help you!

link.title: How Do Home Warranties Benefit Both Buyers and Sellers?

entry.title: How to Avoid Surprise Costs When Buying an Iowa Home
entry.content:
There tend to be a few common costs that buyers overlook when they purchase their home. Today, I have a full list of these items that will help buyers avoid getting surprised by extra costs. 

Want to sell your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report
Want to buy a Central Iowa home? Search all the homes on the MLS
When you buy a home, there are some hidden costs that you should be aware of.
While the home shopping process can be exciting, certain costs tend to sneak up on buyers. Here are some key tips to help you be fully informed when buying:

  1. Property taxes. Of your monthly house payments, property taxes are the item that can fluctuate the most during the lifetime of your mortgage. That's why it's important to pay attention to the assessed value of your home and the tax rates in the area you chose. If the seller you're buying from did a great job with home renovations but they're not reflected in the assessed value, be prepared for the potential of your property taxes jumping up in the next year or so.
  2. Insurance costs. Many people have a general idea of homeowners insurance based on the value of the home they buy, but some special considerations can greatly affect the costs. For example, acreages that are long distances from a fire station can cause the cost to go up exponentially. Another would be having an in-ground swimming pool. If you have any special circumstances, be sure to check what your insurance agent's rate is.
    3. Many buyers forget to consider extra costs for a new home, like window treatments and installing landscaping.
  3. Utility bills. Here in Iowa when we go from five below to 105 degrees over the course of the year, we really use our heating and cooling systems. It's important to get a sense of the cost of running and maintaining them, and it's very easy for us to get a 12- to 24-month average from a provider. Having that knowledge up front really helps you prepare.
  4. Maintenance costs. We all know there will be maintenance involvedâ€”it's part of the fun of owning a new place. There are, however, some things people don't think about as much. Older homes, for example, will have a great, mature landscape with lots of trees and plants, but it can be costly to maintain with watering and other maintenance costs. With newer homes, people often overlook things like the cost of window treatments, landscaping installation, and all the things you need to buy because no one has lived there before.
All these items are very easy to overcome; it's all about having the knowledge up front instead of getting surprised down the road.
If you have any other questions about the costs of homeownership or you're thinking about buying or selling a central Iowa home, just give me a call. I'd be happy to help you!

link.title: How to Avoid Surprise Costs When Buying an Iowa Home

entry.title: How Do You Know When to Sell Your Home?
entry.content:
There is no â€œrightâ€ time to sell your home; however, there are certain factors you can look at to determine whatâ€™s best in your specific situation.  

Want to sell your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report
Want to buy a Central Iowa home? Search all the homes on the MLS

When is the best time to sell your home?
Unfortunately, thereâ€™s no straightforward answer to that question. Truthfully (and against a lot of conventional wisdom that suggests a seasonal market), we see homes sell every month of the year in central Iowa.
In cold weather months, there might not be as many active buyers looking at homes, but the buyers that are out there are far more serious. This is because theyâ€™re usually driven by life events like a job relocation or the birth of a new baby. Hence, as a home seller during these months, you may not get a higher volume of buyers, but you will get a higher quality of buyers.
"We see homes sell every month of the year in central Iowa."
Another factor to consider in deciding when to sell your home is your level of competition. If youâ€™re deciding between spring, summer, fall, and winter, what will you be up against during those different seasons?
If your house is in a newer neighborhood (e.g., the majority of the homes in the neighborhood were built in the last five to 10 years), one thing you need to be specifically mindful of is how much construction is happening in that area. There are some real advantages for a seller in a newer neighborhood when the builders have slowed down because of weather.
When it comes to helping you make the best decision regarding your home sale, we donâ€™t deal in speculationâ€”we strategize based on many different concrete factors. If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to us. Weâ€™re here to help!

entry.title: Breaking Down the Abstracting Process
entry.content:
If youâ€™re thinking about selling your home sometime in the near future, youâ€™ll need to update your abstract. Here is what that means.

Want to sell your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report
Want to buy a Central Iowa home? Search all the homes on the MLS

One thing that makes Iowa really unique when selling real estate is the fact that we are one of the few states in the country that utilizes abstracting.

What is an abstract? If you closed on a home in the past, you may recall that someone handed you a thick, legal-sized binder filled with all sorts of old papers and information, labeled â€œabstract.â€ Attorneys will tell you to guard these documents with your life because theyâ€™re so expensive to replace.

"It will cost between $300 and $500 to update the abstract."

When you go to sell your home, youâ€™ll need to update that abstract. Weâ€™ll send that abstract to a local abstractor in the county in which your property is held, they will update it, then ship it to whoever the buyer is using as a title opinion attorney. That attorney will then look over the abstract and all of the information thatâ€™s contained in it, including the history of the property, which will go back all the way to when the land was deeded over from the U.S. government. They will look for any clouds on the title that need to be cleared.

The cost of updating your abstract will be somewhere around $300 to $600, depending on the county that you live in, how long itâ€™s been since you last had the abstract updated, as well as other variables depending on your specific real estate situation.   

In other states, title insurance will usually take the place of an abstract. This is a very different process, but it works for us here in Iowa!

If you have any other questions about abstracting or anything else related to real estate, feel free to reach out and give me a call or send me an email. Iâ€™d be happy to help you!

entry.title: How Revenue Stamps Affect Your Home Purchase
entry.content:
Revenue stamps are mandated by the state of Iowa, so itâ€™s important that you know what they are and how they are calculated.

Want to sell your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report
Want to buy a Central Iowa home? Search all the homes on the MLS

A revenue stamp is a fee you incur in selling your home on both the estimate of proceeds (which youâ€™d be provided by your Realtor) and on the closing disclosure statement when you get ready to close on the home. 

"A revenue stamp is a fee on both the estimate of proceeds and the disclosure statement."

Revenue stamps are mandated by the state of Iowa. They are made payable to the county treasurerâ€™s office in the county in which you close. Revenue stamps are calculated by taking the sale price, deducting $500 off the top (which is exempt from the fee), and calculating that based on $1.60 per $1,000 of value.

For example, for a home that sells for $100,000, you would pay slightly less than $160 for your revenue stamp fee.

If you have any questions about revenue stamps and how theyâ€™re calculated, feel free to give us a call or send us an email. Weâ€™d be happy to help in any way we can!

link.title: How Revenue Stamps Affect Your Home Purchase

entry.title: Don't Be Caught off Guard by a Major Cost When Selling Your Home
entry.content:
When you are preparing to sell your home, we will sit down with you and go over a couple of different things. One of those things is an estimate of proceeds. We will break down all the different costs you can expect as a seller. One fee that comes as a huge surprise is the property tax proration. 

The tax proration surprises sellers for a couple of different reasons. First of all, it is one of the largest expenses that affects your bottom line when selling. The other thing sellers say is, â€œWhy do I need to pay this? I am already up-to-date with my property taxes.â€ 

In Iowa, property taxes are a little complicated. Iowa property taxes run on a fiscal year system instead of a calendar year. In addition to that, we pay property taxes in arrears, which means after the fact. That creates a whole other layer of complication. 


"Iowa pays property taxes in arrears, which makes the process more complicated."

You have probably received your property tax bill this month. If so, you will notice that you can pay those taxes in two installments. One is due in September of 2016 and the other is due in March of 2017. That property tax bill is actually for the fiscal year of 2015. In other words, you will pay property taxes for the fiscal year of July 1, 2015 through December 31, 2015 in the September 2016 installment. You will then pay for January 1, 2016 through June 30, 206 in the March 2017 installment. 

When we do an estimate of proceeds, we use one year of property taxes as an estimate. Depending on the month you close on your property, you will have anywhere from 10 to 14 months you are crediting. 

Remember, you will have to pay the tax proration whether you work with a Realtor or not. Selling your home on your own does not get you out of this. The tax proration is simply a byproduct of the fact that we pay property taxes in arrears in Iowa. 

However, you should work with a real estate professional when selling your home in order to successfully navigate situations like this one. If you have any questions about the cost of selling your home or about real estate in general, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

link.title: Don't Be Caught off Guard by a Major Cost When Selling Your Home

entry.title: How to Win the Home You Want in Central Iowa
entry.content:
So now that youâ€™ve done the fun part-searched around for some homes, and found the one you want-what happens next? How do you make the offer so that you can successfully purchase this home?

"Donâ€™t make it all about the money."

There are three important things to keep in mind:
  1. You must act quickly. In todayâ€™s market, homes do not sit long when theyâ€™re priced well and in good condition. If youâ€™ve identified the right home, make sure that you donâ€™t overthink the process of submitting an offer for it, otherwise someone might swoop in and steal it from under your nose.
  2. You must be reasonable. In the Des Moines metro area, most homes sell within 1% and 2% of the list price. Whether thatâ€™s above or below depends on the market area. Itâ€™s not a successful strategy, even when weâ€™re trying to test the seller, to approach them with an offer thatâ€™s only 90% of the list value. All that will do is upset them and give off the impression that youâ€™re not a serious buyer.
  3. Donâ€™t make it all about the money. Instead of getting caught up in the facts and figures, try utilizing some other terms that might make your offer more attractive to the seller. These terms can include having a flexible closing and possession date, what kind of personal property gets delegated, and having a shorter inspection period. There are many different ways we can mold the offer so that it isnâ€™t exclusively focused on price. Remember - this property was likely the sellerâ€™s home. They might still have a great deal of emotional connection to it. When you share with them why you love it and why you could see your family living there, it appeals to their emotions. 

Now is not the time to be working with someone who is just a hobbyist. You need a negotiation expert. This distinction will make the difference between successfully getting the home you want or settling for your second or third option. 

As always, if you have any questions, please give us a call or send us an email. We would be happy to help you!

  3. Negotiation strategy. Because we go through this all the time, we have knowledge on different ways you can approach a situation as a buyer or seller in order to meet your goals. entry.title: The Benefits of Working with the University of Iowa Credit Union
entry.content:
Selling your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report  
Buying a Central Iowa home? Search all homes for sale

The SOLDwisch Team has teamed up with the University of Iowa Credit Union because there are some really great features they offer that we think would benefit our clients. There are many advantages to getting a mortgage through them.

They're business plan focuses on becoming the leader when it comes to having the lowest available rates and the lowest fees. Additionally, they offer zero down payment programs, which is fairly uncommon in today's lending environment. Based on the sheer volume of clientele that they work with, the level of expertise they have to have as loan originators helps them put together some pretty incredible financing options for the people they work with.

 
One thing the SOLDwisch Team has noticed is the fact that the University of Iowa Credit Union offers some opportunities for people that other banks don't. They handle their loans on a more case-by-case basis than most other lending institutions. They see it in two ways: secondary market loans where applicants need to fit into a predefined box of characteristics and in-house products that allow them to grant loans in situations where it simply makes sense. They simply want to help people accomplish their goals.

They work out of a leased office space in West Des Moines and are currently working on building their own location. They started out as a credit union for the employees of the University of Iowa hospital back in 1938. The rules and regulations have since changed and progressed so that as long as you live and work in a community they serve, you can join!

They cover a huge area in the state and are currently the largest credit union in the state of Iowa! Additionally, they are number two nationally in total return to member. This means that they were voted the most competitive when it comes to giving the best rates on mortgages, the lowest fees, and the highest rates on their deposit accountants. They are very proud of this distinction, and would love to help you benefit from their services!

If you have any questions or comments about today's topic, or if you need real estate assistance of any kind, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. We would love to hear from you!

link.title: The Benefits of Working with the University of Iowa Credit Union

entry.title: Obtaining a Mortgage in Central Iowa
entry.content:
Selling your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report  
Buying a Central Iowa home? Search all homes for sale
 
Today we are excited to be joined by Patrick St. John from the University of Iowa Community Credit Union. As we launch into 2016, you might be thinking about what kind of home youâ€™ll want this year, and what kind of mortgage you can get in order to pay for that home. First, letâ€™s talk about some of the key points to remember when preparing to get a mortgage.

The first thing you need to figure out is who to talk to. As soon as youâ€™re thinking about buying, you should talk with a lender. Itâ€™s smart to know what you can or canâ€™t qualify for before you start looking.

There are some changes that have taken place recently in the mortgage world that you should be aware of. These changes have to do with the changing of regulations in the industry, and there have been some added requirements to the process. Typically, it takes between 30-60 days to get through the entire process, but now it will take a little longer, probably at least 45 days.

If youâ€™ve been worrying about saving up for a down payment, you might not need to. There are plenty of mortgage products available at 0% down, with a pretty attractive rate. Even with traditional financing methods, like FHA, you should be able to get any product with 5% down. The days of needing 20% down are over which is opening the door for a lot of buyers.


The time to buy in 2016 is now. If you have any questions about the mortgage process or want to get qualified for a home, give Patrick a call at 319-551-1180. If you have any other questions about real estate or youâ€™re looking to buy or sell in Central Iowa, give us a call or send us an email. We look forward to speaking with you!

entry.title: Should You Wait Until Spring to Sell Your Central Iowa Home?

Is fall the right time to sell your home? A lot of our clients at this time of year think they should wait until spring to put their home on the market. However, fall is a wonderful time to be on the market, especially with Iowa's beautiful fall weather!
One great advantage of being on the market in the fall is that a lot of people have the traditional notion that homes only sell in the spring and summer. They wait to list their homes until spring, which means less competition for you!
Today's buyers do most of their searching online, so the home search is no longer seasonal. You can sell your home at any point during the year. Those buyers are just waiting for the right home to come onto the market before they pull the trigger. That home might just be yours!


Another advantage of selling in the fall is that summer buyers are not always serious. They often casually look at homes. Serious buyers who have a real need to make a change are out there house hunting in the fall.
Finally, Google reveals home searching online goes up dramatically during the holiday season and the cooler months. During this time, having exposure online makes you a great focus for potential buyers.
Let go of the misconception that spring is the best time to sell. Fall can be an especially great time to sell your home. If you have any questions for me, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

entry.title: How to Avoid the Potentially Deadly Threat of Radon Gas
entry.content:
Selling your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report  
Buying a Central Iowa home? Search all homes for sale

Have you ever heard of radon? The name might ring a bell, but many homeowners don't know how common it is in homes throughout Central Iowa.
Radon is a gas in the soil that comes from a breakdown of uranium. It's a radioactive gas that can cause cancer if exposed to for a prolonged period of time. Unfortunately, Iowa is the number one state in the country for radon concentration. In fact, all 99 counties in Iowa are in the high-risk category!
If you get a test and find out that there are high radon levels in your home, what does that mean? Well, the EPA has established the level of 4.0 as the point at which action should be taken. If your home has a radon level of 4.0 or greater, you need to get radon mitigation, which is a venting system that is installed to lower radon levels. It's a simple pipe that only takes four hours to install and will protect the home from dangerous levels of the gas.


Ameriserv is a company that started six years ago that focuses on the testing and mitigating of radon. They have seven radon measurement specialists and four mitigation specialists, and are a state-certified company that aims to protect Iowans from toxic levels of radon. We have a special relationship with Ameriserv that allows for a special discount for people that work with us, making an already affordable service even cheaper!
Radon can be a potential problem for a home, as it poses many health risks, but it is a very easy problem to solve! If you would like to get in touch with Ameriserv, or if you need real estate assistance of any kind, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. We would love to assist you in any way we can!

link.title: How to Avoid the Potentially Deadly Threat of Radon Gas

You need to be careful when basing your homeâ€™s value on an automated home valuation site like Zillow. If you take a look at their fine print, you can see that it states they are accurate about 7% of the time. That means the other 93% of the time, they are inaccurate! If I was inaccurate 93% of the time, there is no way I would have been in business for 15 years.

Accuracy is very important when valuing a home. I would rather hurt you with the truth and an accurate, objective valuation, than make you feel good with a lie. The truth is, Zillow has not been inside your home. They are basing their value of basic facts and figures, without getting the full picture of your homeâ€™s value.

entry.title: Market Value vs. Assessed Value vs. Appraised Value
entry.content:
Selling your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report  
Buying a Central Iowa home? Search all homes for sale

Today we're going to talk about the differences between market value, assessed value, and appraised value. These different values can cause confusion when it comes to pricing your home, so it's important to know what each of them are.

Market value is what a home will sell for when it's reasonably exposed to the market. That number can vary, depending on timing, home inventory, and the motivation of buyers and sellers. Market value is based on current market trends.

Assessed value is the amount that the County Assessor's office puts on the home based on their estimate of what the home value is for taxation purposes. It's not uncommon for assessments to be nowhere close to the market value, but since it's usually lower, it doesn't matter.You're not going to call the Assessor and ask for a higher assessed value so you can pay higher taxes.


The appraised value is done on the bank's behalf in order to prove that the collateral securing the mortgage is enough to cover the risk. An appraiser looks at square footage, the number of bedrooms, and the number of bathrooms. Updates and features of the home don't necessarily matter to the appraiser. As the market improves in Central Iowa, the appraisals can come in a little low from time to time, as the appraisal is based on old information. That's good news for buyers, because they can perhaps negotiate a lower price on the home.

We look at all these factors during the home buying process. If you have any questions, give us a call or send us an email. We look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: Market Value vs. Assessed Value vs. Appraised Value

  2. Varied Industries Building

entry.title: Three Ways to Win a Home in a Hot Central Iowa Market
entry.content:
Selling your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report 
Buying a Central Iowa home? Search all homes for sale

Inventory is quite low in Central Iowa right now, and this means that you'll be facing stiff competition if you're looking to buy a home. You may be placing offers on homes that already have two or three willing buyers, and this means that your offer will need to stand out above them all.

Negotiating on homes becomes different and more strategic when inventory is low. However, there are three keys to success that we've found when negotiating in this market.
  1. Be prepared to act quickly. This involves knowing what you want and being able to pull the trigger when you see a home that suits your needs. Homes are selling in less than a week, so act on your impulses.
  2. Make a strong offer from the beginning. Now is not the time to quibble with sellers. You need to prove to them that you're very serious about buying a home. Make a strong offer to set yourself apart as a willing buyer, and if it is passed over or rejected, find comfort in the fact that you did everything you could to try and win that home.
  3. Write a letter to the seller. Let them know a little about you and why you love their home. A little personal touch can go a long way in a deeply emotional transaction like this, and sometimes sellers will surprise you with how they respond to heartfelt communication.
These three simple things have been key to buyers in our local market, so we hope that they can help you to find good homes. If you're having trouble buying in Central Iowa, please don't hesitate to contact our team. We would be more than happy to help you find a good home!

link.title: Three Ways to Win a Home in a Hot Central Iowa Market

If you're planning on moving within the next year or so, it's never too early to talk to a mortgage banker. When you do, you'll learn how the entire process will play out; the mortgage professional will pull your credit and make sure you're in good financial standing before you begin looking for homes. If there are problems with your credit, coming in early will give you plenty of time to address them.

If you come in early and your finances are in good order, it's simply a matter of waiting for your lender to get you prepared with the right documentation. They will explain the funds you'll need in order to close, what kind of loan you are eligible for, and other minutiae of the process. Your lender will need two years of full tax returns, two years of W2s, your last 30 days of pay stubs, and also two months of bank statements.

Lincoln Savings Bank is a small community bank that started in 1902 in the Waterloo area. In 2011, they moved to the Des Moines Metro area, and are here in Central Iowa to serve the community. entry.title: Are You Eligible for a Mortgage?
entry.content:
Selling your Central Iowa home? Get a free home value report 
Buying a Central Iowa home? Search all homes for sale

P.S. Thank you to all our contributors for their real estate questions from our past email. You will all be receiving a $25 gift card! 

Lately, we've received many questions from first-time home buyers about how the mortgage process works. To demystify the process a bit, we brought in Jenny Green of Lincoln Savings Bank to answer some viewer questions.

How much money should you prepare to put down?
There are several products available for first-time home buyers. We have conventional loans (requires a 5% down payment), FHA loans (3.5% down), and USDA loans (0%), which are great for people who are looking to move into a rural area. Typically, we want our buyers to bring at least 3.5% of the down payment to the table.

Should buyers have an idea of their credit standing before beginning the process?
First-time buyers should contact a mortgage banker and get a pre-qualification before they start looking. This will let you know what you can afford and what kind of payments you can comfortably make.

What are closing costs?
Typically, closing costs include appraisals, title costs, settlement agent's closing fees, and the credit report. Sometimes, we ask the sellers to pay some of the closing costs, and it usually works well. Sellers are typically good about giving $2,000-$3,000 toward the closing costs, which typically covers them all.

Are there any incentives for first-time home buyers?
The Iowa Finance Authority has a number of incentives for first-time home buyers, as well as for second- and third-time home buyers. They have a $2,500 grant that can go toward your down payment, your closing costs, or any of the other fees associated with the transaction.

If you would like to speak with Jenny about this topic in more detail, you can reach her by phone at (515) 222-0123 Ext. 2506 or by email at JenniferG@mylsb.com. As always, if you need real estate assistance of any kind, don't hesitate to reach out to us! We would love to hear from you!

entry.title: Are Newly Constructed Homes or Old Homes the Better Choice in Central Iowa?
entry.content:
The Central Iowa real estate market is diverse with both buyers and sellers alike seeking a variety of different properties. As a prospective seller, you can find out the market value of your property with a free home value report right here, or if you're looking to purchase in the Central Iowa click here for full MLS access. Always feel free to reach out to us for any questions regarding the current market conditions, or the value of your property at 515-229-9764.

 If you're thinking about moving, you've probably considered whether you want to build a new home or purchase an older one. Today, we want to share some tips so you can make the decision that's right for you and your family. 

There are many advantages to new construction. For one, the builder will use the latest and greatest designs to give your home a very modern feel, and without having to do any of the work yourself. New homes also have great warranties. Often, if any defects come about in a year or so, they'll come and repair them for you. Warranties make your life a bit easier, especially if you don't want to worry about maintenance in the near future. With new construction, the builder will often work with a mortgage professional to create a special financing package. This makes it very easy to finance a new home, and it even offers some special perks.

Older homes also offer some great advantages. Typically, these homes have a lot of character, and have features like interesting woodwork, lots of built-ins, unique fireplaces, and other things that are difficult to duplicate in new construction homes. In addition to some of their unique characteristics, older homes are usually in more mature neighborhoods than newly constructed homes; extensive landscaping, big trees, and other things that are very difficult to find are just a few of the benefits. Lastly, there is simply an overall uniqueness, whereas new construction homes tend to be built in similar styles.

So, what's right for you? It depends. What kind of lifestyle do you have? What do you enjoy doing? Do you have a tolerance for maintenance? One thing we like to do with buyers is have a consultation. We get together with you and go through what your lifestyle needs are, both today and in the future, so we are able to guide you to what's going to be a better fit for you and your needs!

If you have questions about how we can help, or would like real estate assistance of any kind, we're here to help! Give us a call or shoot us an email for the expert service you deserve!

Thanks for stopping by, and have a lovely day!

entry.title: What Are the Advantages of Buying a HUD Home?
entry.content:
The Central Iowa real estate market is diverse with both buyers and sellers alike seeking a variety of different properties. As a prospective seller, you can find out the market value of your property with a free home value report right here, or if you're looking to purchase in the Central Iowa click here for full MLS access. Always feel free to reach out to us for any questions regarding the current market conditions, or the value of your property at 515-229-9764.

Today, we want to discuss the advantages of buying a HUD home.

What exactly is a HUD home? If you're unsure, you're not alone. A HUD home is a 1-4 unit residential dwelling acquired from the Department of Housing and Urban Development as a result of a foreclosure on an FHA-insured mortgage. HUD takes the home into its inventory and sells it to recover the lost funds. 

How does it work? Homes are sold through a closed bidding process online. Because it's an unorthodox process, it's very important that you work with an agent that understands exactly how the bidding process works and knows what to expect when representing you as a buyer. HUD has a property management company that goes into the home first and does a property inspection that's available for viewing on HUDhomestore.com. This ensures that you'll have an idea of the general condition of the home.

When buying a HUD home, you will also have an opportunity to turn on utilities and perform your own inspection after you have an accepted bid. HUD gives priority to owner-occupant buyers, which means you don't have to worry about being outbid by a cash investor on a desirable home in a great neighborhood. Generally, depending on the type of bid period established, you will have up to 30 days where only owner-occupants can place bids. 

Another advantage of a HUD home is the ability to negotiate closing costs into the purchase. If you need to have some of the closing fees rolled into the purchasing price in order to give you the buying power that you need, you're able to negotiate up to 3% of the sales price to help you with the purchase.

An advantage of working with the Misty SOLDwisch Team is our five-plus years of experience listing HUD homes. We would love to help you get a great deal on a great home. Give us a call or shoot us an email if you would like to purchase a HUD home, or if you have any questions about real estate in general. We would love to hear from you!

link.title: What Are the Advantages of Buying a HUD Home?

entry.title: 2 Things Sellers Do that Ruin Their Home Sale
entry.content:
The Central Iowa real estate market is diverse with both buyers and sellers alike seeking a variety of different properties. As a prospective seller, you can find out the market value of your property with a free home value report right here, or if you're looking to purchase in the Central Iowa click here for full MLS access. Always feel free to reach out to us for any questions regarding the current market conditions, or the value of your property at 515-229-9764.


The average homeowner is unaware of how difficult it can be to sell their home, especially if they want to sell it quickly and for top dollar.  Today, we're going to discuss common mistakes people make when they're getting ready to sell their home. By taking care to avoid these pitfalls, you can rest assured that your home sale will be a successful one.
  • Make sure your home is in good condition. Many people don't realize how important carpet and paint are. Stained or worn out carpet is the best way to deter buyers, who are incredibly visual. The presentation of properties online is what brings people through the door - paint and carpet are huge factors in making that happen.

    Take advantage of a home walk through.     When selling your home with us, as a benefit to you, we offer a walk through of your home to give you tips on what you can do to your home to make it show in its best light. 
  • Price your home correctly! When we list your home, we sit down and take a look at homes that have recently sold on the market, as well as what your home will be competing against. In order to get as close as possible to your list price, you need to price your home competitively. This is something we work on closely with our sellers to ensure they achieve their financial goals.

If you want your home to be sold quickly and for top dollar, you need to take a look at the things other sellers do wrong. We hope these tips will be helpful in the sale of your home.

If you have any questions about this topic, or would like to discuss anything pertaining to real estate, we would love to chat. Give us a call or shoot us an email, and we'll help you with whatever you need. Thanks, and we look forward to talking to you soon!

entry.title: Will a Balanced Market Open an Opportunity for You to Buy and Sell?
entry.content:
The Central Iowa real estate market is diverse with both buyers and sellers alike seeking a variety of different properties. As a prospective seller, you can find out the market value of your property with a free home value report right here, or if you're looking to purchase in the Central Iowa click here for full MLS access. Always feel free to reach out to us for any questions regarding the current market conditions, or the value of your property at 515-229-9764.

Thanks for joining us today on our blog. We are going to discuss the current real estate conditions here in Central Iowa and what they mean for you. 

As the year winds down and we head towards winter, we are asked all the time by clients if they should try to buy and sell real estate now, at the end of the year, or wait until next spring to do so. There is definitely a perceived seasonality in the Iowa market, but that doesn't necessarily mean it exists. 

It's more important to look at supply and demand than the time of the year. This basic economic principle is used daily when discussing the market and its health. 

When trying to determine what kind of market we are in, the main indicator as to where we lie is the amount of inventory. In a balanced market there is usually around 6 months of inventory, meaning that it would take 6 months to sell all available homes if no new homes came on the market. A buyer's market is when we have a surplus of inventory, over 6 months. A seller's market is when we have a lack of inventory for our buyers.

So far this year, we have seen all 3. At the beginning of the year it was definitely a buyer's market, then transitioned to a hot seller's market in the spring and summer. Right now, we are starting to see a bit of a slowdown, resulting in a more healthy, balanced market. This is very beneficial for those who want to buy and sell right now. 

When timing your next real estate move, don't look so much into the calendar as much as when the move will work for you. That is the most important thing. 

 If you have any questions at all for us, please feel free to give us a call or send us an email. We would love to help out.

link.title: Will a Balanced Market Open an Opportunity for You to Buy and Sell?
